column1: Will the Liberal Party win a majority of seats in the 2021 Canadian parliamentary elections?
column6: ['Elections and Referenda', 'Non-US Politics']

Final update. Still hedging b/c the polls (338, CBC) continue to give ~15% probability to a Liberal majority. I think—and hope—they’re wrong and it should be 0-5%, but election results can be unpredictable.

1- The last english debate give a better momentum for the Bloc Québecois and a lesser for the PC (Quebec premier endorse those two parties); 2- The Liberal party take a stand for vaccine. That give a momentum for the PCC who voted mainly for the PC; 3- The Liberal Party offers many promises in the social area so the NPD suffer a lot; My projection made from polls: Bloc Québecois 29 Conservateur 119 Liberal 150 NPD 38 Green 2

Election questions are the worst! 338 today gives a 15% chance for a Liberal majority. What may be more interesting, however, is the statement that in 2019 pollsters underestimated the Liberal result and overestimated that of the NDP. May be different this time (disillusionment with the cult of Trudeau—maybe?; some known Liberal candidates not running due to scandals or retirement), but worth hedging IMO. https://twitter.com/338canada/status/1439049214865125377

Good analysis by @Ziewert below (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1333994), but I’m lowering again, mainly because even the CBC poll gives 12% to a Grit majority, and they tend to paint a slightly more favourable picture for the Liberals. It’s very very likely we’ll be back where we started come September 21 (or later — https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-elections-canada-warns-of-problems-delays-ahead-of-voting-day/), or see a slimmed down minority for the Liberal government. If I’m wrong and Trudeau does get a majority, I’ll have more things to be upset and worried about than a bad Brier score. Polls, 4 days until the election: https://twitter.com/canadianpolling/status/1438664964177289217
Increasing from 7 up to 12%.

Angus Reid suggests the two biggest parties might get less than 1/3 of the vote each: https://angusreid.org/federal-election-post-debate/ Why are the polls tightening up after a drop for the Liberals? Part of it is the divide in the country, and possibly the surge of a more far-right PPC (vis-a-vis a very centrist Conservative leader O’Toole) that’s taking away from the Conservative vote. There’s also a view it may come down to the results in British Columbia, where early vote so far suggests the more left-wing NDP will put a dent in the Liberal support. I’ll be very surprised, and not in a positive way, if JT pulls off a majority.
https://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/federal-election-2021/liberals-see-a-jump-in-support-after-back-to-back-debates-nanos-1.5581539 https://newsinteractives.cbc.ca/elections/poll-tracker/canada/

Up, as the CBC reports polling where a Liberal majority is a possibility. They rate it at 17%. Seems like some of the less attentive voters are buying into Trudeau’s fake wedges on guns, abortion, and now daycare. So far, Jody Wilson Raybould’s book detailing a high-profile ethical scandal and obstruction of justice JT was involved in(/directed) hasn’t had any effect, it seems. https://newsinteractives.cbc.ca/elections/poll-tracker/canada/
Only chance would be if Donald Trump became a Canadian citizen before the polls closed
It is next week. Time to go 0.
No change from the debates, Legault came out for the Conservatives. 338 has not shifted, but I am.
Looks like a minority from this angle

Projections on September 10th are for the Liberals to have 140 seats. The CPC, 136 and the NDP (as potential kingmakers) with 35 The polls are forecasting a minority government with a few seats between the Liberals and Conservatives with a need to negotiate with the NDP. The reported view is that of a frustration as to why the election was called now and apprehension over a Conservative Government. So, considering that a majority of seats means +169, the Liberal party is not going to achieve this.
Liberals have recovered slightly in the polls and with a more efficient vote distribution (aka Ontario) they have slightly improved their odds of a majority. Bumping from 3 up to 7.
The english debate didn't do any "winner", there was nothing there to change the course of this election.
Political debate tonight: Trudeau didn't do wrong or right enough to change the course of this election.

CBC's polling is showing a skew to Liberal seats (1), while the Liberals are lagging in overall polling, his party appears more likely to win the majority of seats only only appear to be lead in 7 of 11 regions (2). On top of all that, they took the most seats at the last election without winning popular support (3). This doesn't mean the Libs are a shoe-in, but I think the crowd is being a little harsh given the polling numbers.

Haven't updated in a while. Polls looking very poor for Trudeau, though there's still time and a majority isn't fully out of reach yet. Will have to watch any shifts in momentum closely over the next couple weeks as polling can lag sentiment a little, esp. in the last few days before the election.

The current polls show a narrow lead by the Conservatives of about 2,3,4 % over the Liberals which undulates depending on the poll and day. Trudeau has to overcome this lead and there has been little movement in the last week. A majority of seats by the Liberals is looking unlikely.
Halfway point, National Post suggests Trudeau now might not even *win*, so how would they get a majority then?

Justin Trudeau Tumbles Further Behind Tory 'Freight Train' in Canada Election https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-09-03/trudeau-tumbles-further-behind-conservative-freight-train Canada federal election: How much trouble is Trudeau in? https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-58389802 [Sep 3, 2021]
Electoral debate tonight in french: nothing enough to change the polls in Quebec.

I bow to the arbiter as to the correct definition of a majority. However, my misunderstanding maybe due to the separation/differences of a common language. A plurality vote in the US is known as a relative majority in the UK and Commonwealth. That being said, the latest polls show the Liberals as having slipped against the Conservatives and seeing as the Liberals began the campaign as a minority Government, their chances of obtaining 170 (majority vote) appear to be slim. Current forecasts show the Liberals and Conservatives on 139 seats each.

Stranger things have happened but they seem to be doing most things wrong and the conservatives are surging, so I'd be shocked if they pull it out at this point. They may still form government with a NDP coalition but this is looking messy...
Updated based on latest 338. But debates have not happened so still chance albeit small in some reversal
Having originally said it could be a blip, liberal polling numbers have now been in freefall for 2 weeks

According to the Spectator magazine, Trudeau’s move to call for a snap election may have backfired. Rather than the aim to gain a majority, the Conservatives have a surge in the polls with the Liberals slipping albeit with slight recovery. The gap appears, according to the polls to be closing. https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/is-troubled-trudeau-the-new-theresa-may-

The Liberal party is not popular. The minority government was working sufficiently well to not need an election now. The election call was badly timed. Trudeau is not personally popular but he is the least worst of the leadership candidates. He will probably emerge with another minority government.
Canada is a left leaning country
Barring a major reversal, this is barely minority territory or a CPC win.

Trudeau has failed to impress and squandered many opportunities to capitalize on the goodwill and optimism that initially swept him into office. He has not earned and is not likely to win a majority for the Liberals. It remains to be seen whether it is the NDP or the Conservatives who pick up seats and that will likely reflect the make-up of individual ridings. The recent win in Nova Scotia would seem to be encouraging for the Conservatives but in other parts of the country, right leaning administrations have bungled the CoVid response and it is unclear whether the country at large will choose to make such a dramatic swing. Typically the NDP might be expected to benefit from a disaffection with the Liberals and apprehension of the Conservatives but social media abounds more with right wing populist sentiment than left wing voices. So many of the anti-Liberal, anti-Trudeau memes are recycled Republican messaging from below the 49th parallel. One bet is probably safe however and that is that the election will have been decided before polls close on the West Coast.

Due to the negative views about Canada's exodus from Afghanistan, fatigue with Trudeau and the Liberals and ongoing Covid issues, I think the voters aren't unhappy enough to vote the Liberals out but not pleased enough to hand him a majority. NDP will have a net gain I think but otherwise status quo
Decreasing based on latest modeling. Majority seems out of reach. https://twitter.com/canadianpolling/status/1432529911877709827

It seems that JT is not campaigning so good. But in the end wach individualnseat is its own race. So without some wind to force a change in the present split in Parliament it is hard to see any cause for 202q not to be a repeat pf the past. So reducing from 25 to 5.

Preamble: I initially vowed to stay away from this question as I don’t want to be tempted to curse on this platform. But since I’m following the election anyway, I’ll remember to reserve my cursing for Twitter. As a caveat, I have strong feelings about the incumbent—and not because he is “speaking moistly.”

Atm hard to tell if the big drop in last week is a temporary Afghanistan-related dip or whether it will stick more, but 12% feels a bit low to me. In both 2015 and 2019 Trudeau was behind for a bit in polls only to get later bounce (though in 2019 obv not enough for majority)

https://globalnews.ca/news/8135771/canada-election-ipsos-week-2/ https://electionarium.com/2021-canadian-election-results-and-predictions/ https://newsinteractives.cbc.ca/elections/poll-tracker/canada/ https://www.wsj.com/articles/trudeau-deploys-vaccine-mandates-as-wedge-issue-in-canadas-election-11629889200 https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/canadian-election-gamble-by-justin-trudeau-backfires-as-liberal-partys-lead-evaporates-37wc2tjs8 polls have liberals below majority seat numbers. support for trudeau has dipped in polls (margins of error around 3%)
Polls indicate that Liberals are not the majority territories they are losing some supporters.

Lowering to 11% based on the latest gaffes and 338 analysis. The trend is moving away from the Libs. NDP holding and Tories picking up most of the changes in sentiment. However still a month to go so there could be another inflection.

It seems any chance at a majority is rapidly evaporating according to https://338canada.com/. In only 3 days its down to 11% and given current public sentiment it's likely even lower. The Afghanistan withdrawl is being pinned on Trudeau, his team has made a few foolish gaffes, and he's taking flak from historic backers, which usually isn't a good sign.
Update for latest numbers: 338 @ 11%; Eric Grenier 28%.
Starting pretty low on this question, just below where 338canada.com has the Liberals' majority chances at, but well below the CBC Poll Tracker's odds.
Will the Conservative win a minority of seats? ... https://338canada.com/?fbclid=IwAR2Tmx_2PvECjVW4Ibm2HCYefNqRhK74EC2pTxImzs6eJdDDsayN6U8FXEA
What are the election issues? It will be both a referendum on Mr. Trudeau's handling of the pandemic and a vote on future plans to the recovery. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-58209031
Trimming downward based on crowd wisdom and hesitation

IIRC, liberals polling is not that much improved from last election 2019. Based on 338 Canada, the margin is big enough that it could improve though, and PMs generally call elections if they think they can win… kinda tempering my expectations they won’t win?
First rule of forecasting: Read the question properly. Not "win" but "win a majority of seats" -- my mistake.
The projection made by CBC poll trackers shows that liberals are going win some seats but are still further away to obtain 170 that are need to get the majority.
Certainly hope not.

338 currently predicts the Liberals taking 155 seats (need 169 for Majority, currently have 155). Liberals had 184 in 2015 when Trudeau took over for Harper but shine of being Pierre Trudeau's son and a force for Canada have worn off with a few scandels (SNC Lavelin). Currently Liberals have 35% support (8.22), while Conservatives are at 30%. Election was called 2 years early and during a rise in Delta cases, meaning the Liberals must have thought this was an advantageous time. Polling data seems to indicate a disconnect with the Liberal decision of calling an election, unless they are worried about things getting even worse. Minority governments can topple easily though and most in Canada only last 2 years. Eric Grenier puts the Liberal estimate at 160 seats and 37% Majority; 338 gives Liberals 26.4% chance of Majority. Starting at 31% (more weight to 338) and a little bump to reflect Liberals potentially knowing something since they could call election at any time.
Politicians very frequently overestimate how popular they are. This looks like a case of that. Stay tuned.
https://newsinteractives.cbc.ca/elections/poll-tracker/canada/
As of Aug 20 https://338canada.com/ has the Liberals pegged at 156.4 +/-36.3 seats and a 27% chance of winning a majority (down from a 58% chance a week earlier just before the election was called).
Adjusting up since others seem to think better chance than I originally forecasted.

Weakening polls, mail in voting problems and the publics perception that the election is unnecessary all point towards Trudeau's gamble not paying off. Handling of the covid crisis (70% vaccinated) may help but with the delta variant on the rise and borders still not fully open I do not think that will be enough.

The first issue is the rationale behind holding a federal election now. A poll held in July, suggests that only 26% of Canadians supported the prospect of a federal election in 2021 (Autumn), 37% not happy and 34% not sure. Reports suggest that there are Liberals questioning the need for an early election (two years ahead of mandated time) considering the risk of going to the polls when they do not have to. Trudeau appears to be searching for a compelling reason (‘big ideas/ Wow factor) as to why he is seeking a third mandate in the middle of a potential fourth wave of the pandemic. The Economist magazine suggests a possible reason for holding the election in 2021 is if held in 2023, it would be more difficult to win as the voters might have tired of a scandal-prone government, a vaccine dividend would have worn off, the Conservative leader Erin O’Toole would be better known, and the administration would be entering its ninth year. A factor that will probably affect the voter turnout it is projected that up to 5 million Canadians will use mail-ballots during the fourth wave of the pandemic. Elderly voters who tend to vote more than others will be deterred by a complex mail-in application process and due to Covid, may not vote. Support for mail-in is stronger amongst New Democrats and Liberals and least popular among Conservatives. 20% of left leaning voters prefer the mail-in option that could affect the outcome of a majority desired by Trudeau.

The campaign doesn't seem start and Trudeau is downward. Hypothesis: 1 - Starting an election in this Covid-19 third wave; 2- The US border wont be open soon; 3- Some people think that Canada didn't do enough, and some think that Canada should not do anything about Afghanistan.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Canadian_federal_election#2021
Basing my probability on polling and Trudeau's recent popularity.

A lot of political announcement have been made from the liberal party, so polls should reflect enthousiasma but, it's not the case. At this time of the campaign, others political parties can just do better than what they did, and it's "hurting" the catch-all party.

Two weeks ago I would have said 95% but now with Trudeaus gaffe, the knock-on from Afghanistan exposing elite incompetence, the apparent rise of third parties like the NDP I am coming in to this at 25%. The leader of the PC party is also showing quite well and the polls are volatile. A key data point is the Liberal loss to the PC in Nova Scotia.

My rationale is here https://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/federal-election-2021-where-might-trudeau-be-most-vulnerable-and-other-big-questions/ They could do it but not much really has changed from the last election. Still there are slme wild cards out there like covid. I am not jjst leaning towards no, pretty sure it is no, but I usually get these questions wrong anyway.
